plant.title: Tulips
plant.toxicity_level: ‚ö†Ô∏è LOW TO MODERATE TOXICITY ‚Äì BULBS ARE MOST DANGEROUS
plant.summary: Tulips contain tulipalin A and B, which are most concentrated in the bulbs. Ingestion can cause drooling, vomiting, and diarrhea. Leaves and flowers are less toxic but still irritating.
plant.what_to_do:
**Low risk from petals‚Äîbut bulbs = high risk.**

1. If your cat chewed a flower: rinse mouth, monitor.
2. If bulbs were ingested: **call vet immediately**.
3. Keep potted tulips or cut bouquets on high surfaces.
4. Never compost tulip bulbs where pets can access.

> üí° Spring tip: Easter and Mother‚Äôs Day bouquets often include tulips‚Äîcheck before gifting!
sources: ASPCA Toxic and Non-Toxic Plants Database
plant.contentHtml: ‚ö†Ô∏è Disclaimer: PawSafePlants provides general educational information only. This content is not veterinary advice. If your cat has been exposed to any plant, contact a licensed veterinarian or the ASPCA Animal Poison Control Center immediately. We do not guarantee the accuracy, completeness, or timeliness of this information. Use at your own risk.
plant.what_to_do_html:
Low risk from petals‚Äîbut bulbs = high risk.

  1. If your cat chewed a flower: rinse mouth, monitor.
  2. If bulbs were ingested: call vet immediately.
  3. Keep potted tulips or cut bouquets on high surfaces.
  4. Never compost tulip bulbs where pets can access.

üí° Spring tip: Easter and Mother‚Äôs Day bouquets often include tulips‚Äîcheck before gifting!
